Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrated molecular and computational sensing (IMACS) for label-free bacteriomics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The PI proposes novel compressed sensing and parallel acquisition imaging approaches to monitor many cells (~thousands) and obtain the unique molecular barcodes via surface enhanced and normal Raman imaging (SERI & NRI) with a throughput advantage ~1000X over existing Raman techniques. Instead of point-scan as used in current confocal Raman microscopy, multi-foci and compressed-sensing snapshot Raman imaging are proposed. To realize large area SERI over mm2, the PI engineers a new class of highly reliable plasmonic surface with hierarchical nanoarchitecture to selectively image cell surfaces and internal organelles (for identification and counting), cell-secreted proteins, enzymes and exotoxins in the extracellular environment (for virulence and biofilm formation assessment), as well as biofilm growth and heterogeneity. Multivariate computational algorithms will be developed and employed in molecular detection and identification, separation of biological fluorescence background, and spatio-spectro-temporal feature extraction, pattern recognition and library matching. IMACS could enable label-free investigation of bacterial sporulation and germination at the population level and network behavior such as quorum sensing and its role in the secretion or recruitment of extracellular factors. IMACS could provide critical information for biolfilm maturation and heterogeneity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Optical microscopy has been a ubiquitous tool in biological and biomedical research. However, traditional microscopy faces the challenge that these entities are either extremely small or transparent. As such, reporter molecules such as stains and dyes are needed as “labels” to warrant detection. Label-free techniques for detection and identification of biomolecules and cells is a potential game changer by providing new capability, higher efficiency, and yet lower cost. Taking advantage of localized surface plasmon resonance, known as collective oscillation of conduction electrons in metal nanostructures, the PI has developed new type of gold and alloy nanostructures for enhanced electric-field localization, which results in better signal amplification from biomarkers that are relevant to physiological monitoring and disease diagnostics. At the heart of this platform lies a unique metamaterial, nanoporous gold disk (NPGD), which features large surface area, uniform and high-density field concentration, and excellent architectural integrity for mass production. To enhance synergy, the PI has also designed and built novel microscopy systems to further enhance detection sensitivity, provide higher data acquisition throughput, and lower the cost.  Finally, machine learning based data analytics has been employed to boost sensor performance. These concerted efforts have brought label-free biosensing and imaging techniques a step closer to translation. On the education and outreach front, the PI has involved many students in various aspects of this project. These trainees came from all levels: postdoctoral, doctoral, undergraduate, and high school. The training activities encompass laboratory experiments, data acquisition and interpretation, research manuscripts, and conference presentations. The specific aims achieved are listed below.

Parallel Raman microscope design and implementation:

The PI has developed two high-throughput Raman microscopes: Line-scan and holographic Raman imaging systems. Both systems have demonstrated 50-100X higher throughput compared to commercial systems. The high throughput would increase the viability of Raman microscopy in biophotonics applications. For example, an image used to take an hour to acquire takes a minute using these systems. These instruments have been employed in many biosensing/imaging projects with results published in peer-reviewed journals. The holographic Raman system has been patented.

Near- and far-field coupling plasmonics and nanoporous gold disk array:

NPGD provides merits for enhanced surface light-matter interactions for sensing and imaging. As individual nanoparticles, NPGD’s plasmon resonance is red-shifted into the near-infrared due to near-field coupling among tiny ligament-like constituents. As an array, far-field coupling causes a blue-shift in the resonance. These coupling mechanisms provide additional “knobs” for fine-tuning the plasmon resonance to a desirable wavelength, while maintaining the large surface area and high-density electric field localization. NPGD can be made using low-cost processing technologies and are attractive for commercial applications. More than 10 peer-reviewed journal papers have been published. One patent has been granted with another one pending.

Development of high-performance, machine-learning boosted biophotonic sensing and imaging techniques:

Disease biomarker such as breast cancer DNA sequence has been sensed using surface-enhance Raman spectroscopy (SERS) and surface-enhanced fluorescence (SEF), with the former providing single molecule sensitivity. Telemorase, a potential cancer biomarker, has been quantified with better sensitivity compared to enzyme-linked immunosorbant assay, and better specificity for enzymatic activities. Novel physiological biomarker sensors for neurotransmitters and metabolites have also been developed. Both Raman and SERS have been employed for detection and identification of bacterial cells in conjunction with computational analysis. A similar approach has been applied to detect renal biomarkers (urine creatinine) with performance competitive with commercial colorimetric assay but much simpler sample preparation. One patent has been granted.

Hyperspectral molecular imaging using spatial light modulator and computational techniques:

The PI has developed a stimulated Raman scattering (SRS) microscope where a Texas Instruments Digital Mirror Device (DMD) is employed as agile wavelength selector of output from a femtosecond laser. The results system can acquire hyperspectral SRS images with 20 spectral bands between 2900-3200 wavenumbers. The PI has developed a near-infrared (NIR) hyperspectral imaging system based on parallel single pixel camera. In the design, a DMD is employed to generate random masks sampling the incoming light field, while a dispersive spectrograph is used to record compressed scene at individual wavelengths. A standard single pixel camera reconstruction algorithm is used to recover the hyperspectral data. One journal paper and one conference paper have been published.

Optical fiber neural probe for deep brain light delivery and electrical recording:

The PI has developed new multimodal neural probes for deep brain light delivery and electrical spike recording. By creative engineering of optical fiber using laser and micromachining, optical fiber probes with side firing windows have been made for localized, multi-site light delivery. Two journal articles have been published and one patent is pending.

Smartphone microscopy:

The PI has developed novel polymer lens sticker that turns a smartphone into a microscope. This technology has drawn phenomenal publicity and become subjects of multiple collaborative projects with local schools. Three journals papers and one patent have been published.
